citation.abstract: On the basis of the known electrophysiologic mechanisms of atrial fibrillation, multiple surgical procedures were designed and tested in dogs to determine the feasibility of developing a surgical cure for human atrial fibrillation. These experimental studies culminated in a surgical approach that effectively creates an electrical maze in the atrium. The atrial incisions prevent atrial reentry and allow sinus impulses to activate the entire atrial myocardium, thereby preserving atrial transport function postoperatively. Since September 1987, this surgical procedure has been applied in seven patients, five with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation of 2 to 9 years' duration and two with chronic atrial fibrillation of 3 and 10 years' duration. All seven patients have been cured of atrial fibrillation and none is receiving any postoperative antiarrhythmic medications.
citation.journal: Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery
citation.title: The surgical treatment of atrial fibrillation. III. Development of a definitive surgical procedure.

wikipedia.title: Minimaze procedure
wikipedia.summary: The mini-maze procedures are cardiac surgery procedures intended to cure atrial fibrillation (AF), a common disturbance of heart rhythm.

wikipedia.title: Cox maze procedure
wikipedia.summary: The Cox maze procedure is a type of heart surgery for atrial fibrillation.

wikipedia.title: James L. Cox
wikipedia.summary: James L. Cox, MD, is an American cardiothoracic surgeon and medical innovator best known for the development of the Cox maze procedure for treatment of atrial fibrillation.
